title: Queen Letizia recycles a Massimo Dutti python print for audiences at Zarzuela Palace in Madrid
text:
She's never less than impeccably turned out for royal engagements, but Queen Letizia of Spain isn't afraid to add an edgy touch to her royal wardrobe in the form of a bold print.

This morning, the Spanish monarch, 47, looked glowing as she donned a snakeskin midi dress from Massimo Dutti to host audiences at Zarzuela Palace with her husband Felipe VI, 51.

The recycled shirt dress, adorned with a reptile print, was first worn by the royal in February 2018 to welcome the President of Peru, Martín Vizcarra, and his wife during their official visit to Spain.

Today, the Spanish royals welcomed the board of the European and Spanish Academy of Dermatology and Venereology.

Queen Letizia of Spain and King Felipe VI welcomed the Europeana nd Spanish Academy of Dermatology and Venereology in Madrid this morning

Sporting a bouncy blow-dry and studded earrings, the Spanish Queen looked stylish in a recycled outfit

Letizia let the print do the talking and paired her monochrome dress with a pair of simple olive green suede pumps by CH Carolina Herrera.

She donned a bouncy blow-dry which framed her face flawlessly, and kept her jewellery low-key, only sporting stud earrings and her favourite ring.

With just a dash of make-up on, the royal looked relaxed as she shook hands with the members of the organisation.

Meanwhile, King Felipe looked smart in a striped suit in navy, which he paired with a mauve tie and lavender shirt.

The Spanish queen sported d a shirt dress from Massimo Dutti with a python print, which she first wore in February 2018

Looking engaged and relaxed, Letizia welcomed the group of scientists and researchers at Zarzuela Palace

The board of the European and Spanish Academy of Dermatology and Venereology visited Zarzuela Palace as part of their 29th annual meeting in the Spanish capital, which will go on until October 13.

Founded in 1987 in Luxembourg, the Academy aims to further the knowledge of health professionals by advancing research, patient care and education within the field of dermatology and venereology, the branch of medicine concerned with venereal diseases.

This week marks the beginning of a busy time for the royals, who will travel to Asturias next week for Hispanic Day.

The royal family will attend the Princess of Asturias Awards next Saturday, in Campoamor Theatre in Oviedo.

Letizia's eldest daughter Leonor, 13, is the honorary president of The Princess of Asturias Foundation, a non-profit organisation which has existed since 1980.

Whilst her husband Felipe VI looked smart in a striped naby suit and mauve tie, Letizia banked on python print and nude heels

The couple seemed to be enjoying a pleasant conversation as their entered the hall of Zarzuela Palace (pictured)

Queen Letizia is gearing up for a few trips, starting with a visit to the Asturias next week with her family, followed by trips to Japan and South Korea

Leonor's father King Felipe VI was the honorary president until he assumed the throne from Juan Carlos in 2014, therefore giving the title to his apparent heir.

It is the first time that Leonor will preside over the Awards, which reward the scientific, technical, cultural, social and humanitarian work carried out at an international level by individuals, institutions or groups of individuals or institutions.

After that, Letizia and Felipe VI will travel to Japan to attend the coronation of Emperor Naruhito, before taking another trip to Korea shortly after.

Letizia gave a benevolent smile as she and her husband stepped away from the group of visitors
description: Queen Letizia of Spain, 47, looked chic at Zarzuela Palace, where  she and King Felipe welcomed members of the European and Spanish Academy of Dermatology and Venereology.
